events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker, speaking in an informative tone, describing gamma ray bursts and fast radio bursts in astrophysics. He further explains the difficulty of detecting these bursts due to interference.

events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker discussing a fast radio burst detected in 2001 using the Parkes telescope in Australia. He speaks in a factual tone, describing how interference can often be mistaken for radio signals, relating a story about pulses of radio interference caused by a local farmer starting his car and microwave ovens in the observatory. He then notes that the telescope was befuddled by microwave ovens at the time. Shifting focus, he mentions that years later, researchers examining the data discovered a strange pattern, describing the data displayed. His tone is academic and informative throughout.

events_list.audio_caption: The clip features a single male speaker in an informative tone, explaining the expected characteristics of a sudden radio burst from outside our galaxy and the concept of dispersion in intergalactic space. The speaker outlines that if space was empty, the pulse would arrive at all frequencies at the same time, but as radio waves go through plasma, lower frequency radio waves slow down. The speaker continues, explaining that as more telescopes discovered the phenomenon, it became clear that it was some sort of extragalactic radio burst, concluding the audio clip.

events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker discussing, in a somewhat academic tone, that "astronomers spotted because of a telescope is not looking at the right place at the right time", but "they're actually incredibly common and frequent". He continues talking about data, mentioning "characteristic downward slope with particular spikes" and that "some are brighter and some are fainter than others". He then gets into specifics about the time period, stating "look at this one here" and "that's less than half a millisecond." The speaker elaborates, giving additional time measurements. He concludes that these are "incredibly short, much shorter than gamma-ray bursts." The speaker infers that "this time is probably not caused by how long the actual radio burst goes on."

events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a single male speaker discussing radio bursts and their characteristics. He notes the frequency of these bursts and speculates they can’t be from one-time events like supernovas. The speaker considers whether these radio bursts repeat. His tone is conversational and speculative. He notes that some do repeat, further suggesting a source that doesn't destroy the object. The speaker ponders whether they all repeat, noting that the time between repetitions may be long. He ends by stating that a lot of people think they have to all repeat, because there aren’t enough objects to produce all these flashes otherwise, and concludes by asking, "So, mystery, what are they?"
